text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This IRM was revised as follows:

Subsection Description of Change Title of IRM The title of this IRM was changed from “AIMS Procedures and Processing Instructions, Adjustments-Miscellaneous” to “AIMS Procedures and Processing Instructions, Credit Transfers and Re- processing Returns.” All sections Various grammatical, editorial, and website address link additions and updates throughout. Identified group Responsibility and Cen- tralized Case Processing (CCP) Responsibility. IRM 4.4.3.1 Renumbered this section. IRM 4.4.3.2 Retitled and updated instructions to add additional details for transferring credits and the requirement to include a statement from the taxpayer. IRM 4.4.3.3 Retitled, updated instructions, and added group responsibility IRM 4.4.3.4 Moved information in this section to IRM 4.4.3.3, retitled, updated instructions, and added group responsibility IRM 4.4.3.5 Moved information in this section to IRM 4.4.3.3, retitled, added CCP and Appeals Processing responsibility, and added website links to forms and other IRM references IRM 4.4.3.6 Moved this information to IRM 4.4.3.7. Added website links to forms and other IRM references, clarified group, CCP and Technical Services responsibilities. IRM 4.4.3.7 Retitled and renumbered to IRM 4.4.3.7.4 IRM 4.4.3.8 Retitled and renumbered to IRM 4.4.3.7.5 and updated the threshold amount from $100 to $200 as reflected in IRM 21.4.5.4.2, Erroneous Refunds IRM 4.4.3.9 Retitled, renumbered, and added additional detail to IRM 4.4.3.8. Added website links and additional details to the instructions IRM 4.4.3.10 Retitled and renumbered to IRM 4.4.3.9 with subsequent sections renumbered accordingly. Addressed statute issues, added separate instructions for reprocessing SB/SE and LB&I cases, included group and CCP responsibility and instructions for Form 3870
Description of Change
Moved information in this section to IRM 4.4.3.3, retitled, updated instructions, and added group responsibility

Subsection Description of Change IRM 4.4.3.10.1 Retitled and renumbered to IRM 4.4.3.9.1 replaced information in this section with instructions for reprocessing SB/SE cases IRM 4.4.3.10.2 Retitled and renumbered to IRM 4.4.3.9.2 replaced information in this section with instructions for reprocessing LB&I cases Exhibit 4.4.3-1 Eliminated exhibit. Incorporated instructions in IRM 4.4.3.9
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 4.4.3, dated March 1, 2003, is superseded. Content in IRM 4.4.8 Credit Transfers and Miscellaneous Adjustments, dated July 11, 2005 is contained in this IRM, as well as, the prior release of IRM 4.4.3 dated March 1, 2003; therefore, it is being obsolesced. IRM.

) Related taxpayer examinations sometimes result in adjustments increasing tax for one taxpayer and decreasing the tax for the other taxpayer. This Payments occurs between parent and subsidiary corporations or between trusts and Between eficiaries. See IRM
, Debit Interest on Liabilities Paid by Offset a Different Taxpayer, for credit availability date and the need to manually compute interest by Centralized Case Processing (CCP). (

) Often the taxpayer will ask that a refund of one taxpayer (primary taxpayer) applied to the additional tax of another taxpayer (related taxpayer). This agreement is documented in the form of a written statement signed by the taxpayer agreeing that its overpayment be credited to the related taxpayer made part of the case file. It is in the interest of IRS to honor this type (
) A credit will be transferred between accounts only if there is a written statement from the taxpayer entitled to the credit requesting such See IRM

, Availability Dates for Overpayments for additional tion. Note: A credit may be transferred from an individual’s Individual Master File account to the same individual’s Business Master File (BMF) account a statement. The BMF account can be the individual’s partnership, excise employment tax account. (

) There may be occasions where the examiner is proposing a refund on a payer’s return; however (according to current transcripts), there is a liability the same tax module that exceeds the proposed overpayment rendering module balance in debt status. Accordingly, the refund cannot be offset to another taxpayer’s deficiency. Advise the taxpayer that their request to the proposed refund to another taxpayer’s deficiency cannot be accommo- dated. The refund will be applied to the debit balance of their account. (
) These procedures should be followed when a refund is to be issued to someone other than the taxpayer in whose name the tax was paid. (
) Provide documentary evidence to permit refunds to be made to, on behalf or in care of any of the following: a. Deceased taxpayers

) There may be occasions where the examiner is proposing a refund on a tax- payer’s return; however (according to current transcripts), there is a liability on the same tax module that exceeds the proposed overpayment rendering the module balance in debt status. Accordingly, the refund cannot be offset to another taxpayer’s deficiency. Advise the taxpayer that their request to offset the proposed refund to another taxpayer’s deficiency cannot be accommo- dated. The refund will be applied to the debit balance of their account.
These procedures should be followed when a refund is to be issued to someone other than the taxpayer in whose name the tax was paid.

Refunds due on joint returns when one spouse has died and no executor or administrator has been or will be appointed, may be made payable to the surviving spouse regardless of the amount. Documen- tary evidence is not required by the surviving spouse if the taxpayer was deceased prior to filing the joint return. On Form
in “Special Features” under “Other instructions (explain)”, add the statement, “Manual Refund-Deceased Taxpayer”.

4.4.3.7.3 (09-16-2011)TechnicalServicesResponsibility
Flag case files involving erroneous refunds by annotating on Form 3198 in “Special Features” under “Other Instructions (explain):”
a. The name, address, and TIN of the taxpayer from whom the erroneous refund is to be recovered; b. The tax period; c. The tax return form number; and d. The amount of refund to be recovered.
4.4 AIMS Procedures and Processing Instructions
) Forward the request for recovery of the erroneous refund to the Campus Ac- counting Branch. (
) Include a transcript of the account from which the erroneous refund was issued. (

) This section contains instructions for the field examiners and CCP when it is necessary to reprocess a return to a correct TIN or a correct tax year. Reminder: IMMINENT OR EXPIRED STATUTE - A notation must be made on Form
, Request for Adjustment, Item
, “Remarks” if the ASED (Assessment Statute Expiration Date) on the incorrect year or TIN has expired or is within six months of expiring. (
) If the examiner suspects there may be an identity theft issue, see IRM Identity Protection Program, for instructions on inputting the appropriate theft indicator(s) on the SSN owner’s account. (

) The examiner must first determine if a paper or electronic return was filed. If paper return was filed, the examiner will secure the original return from Files. a. Command code ESTAB is used to request an original paper return. (Follow local procedures when asking your AIMS/ERCS staff to ESTAB return for you. Go to the AIMS/ERCS website and click on the “Contacts” section. Look for the document titled, “AIMS/ERCS Personnel Listing” to locate your local AIMS/ERCS analyst.) b. If the return cannot be secured through ESTAB, a “Special Search” will need to be done. (Follow local procedures when asking your AIMS/ERCS staff to contact the Campus Files personnel.) Go to the AIMS/ERCS website and click on the “Contacts” section. Look for the document titled, “Contact List - Area Office/Campus Contacts (XLS).” Each Campus has a contact listed for “Files and/or Form

requests.” Contact the person shown as the “Files” contact to help you locate the original return. c. If the original paper return cannot be secured through the prior two contact the taxpayer for a copy of the return. (
) If it is determined that the taxpayer filed an electronic return (determined by the first two digits of the Document Locator Number (DLN), associated with TC
), a TRPRT (tax return print) can be requested and used to reprocess the return. A TRPRT is a graphical (form image) print of a tax return stored TRDB, (tax return database). See Document
, IRS Processing Codes Information, Section
) Campus and File Location Codes, for a list of elec- tronic filing DLNs. (

) If the return still cannot be secured through the prior steps, a “dummy” return may be created. Secure an Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) print using command code TRDBV to obtain the correct tax return numbers to on a tax return you will complete for the reprocessing. Write “Dummy Return” across the top of the tax return. (

Transfers and Reprocessing Returns 4.4.3
a. Annotate in Item

, “Reason for Adjustment,” the following “Return posted to the incorrect tax period or TIN. Please reprocess attached return to the following tax period or TIN” (whichever is appli- cable). b. Provide a complete explanation in Item
, “Remarks,” explaining how account is to be reprocessed. (
) Keep a copy of the return information for your files. Note: The AIMS/ERCS database of the incorrect year/TIN will remain in the status. Do not update the status of the incorrect account to CCP. (
) Forward the return and Form
to CCP by either mail or fax. If the return is secured, it must be mailed. All other forms of the return can be to CCP. (
) If mailing an original return and Form
to CCP, use the following and mail via overnight mail: Areas

) Reprocessing actions take approximately eight weeks to complete. Once the field examiner has been notified by CCP that the reprocessing action has completed, the group will close both AIMS and ERCS controls on the tax period or TIN. (
) AIMS and ERCS controls are closed on the incorrect tax period or TIN by completing Form
, Request for Record Deletion from AIMS, using Disposal Code
Form
is forwarded to the local AIMS/ERCS analyst section for input and updated to status
on ERCS (do not send Form to CCP for input). (
) The group will work with their group secretary and/or local AIMS/ERCS to establish AIMS/ERCS controls on the correct tax period or TIN. (

) Once the return is reprocessed, AIMS/ERCS controls have been closed on incorrect tax period or TIN and AIMS/ERCS controls have been established the correct tax period or TIN, the examiner can forward their completed audit to the appropriate CCP office or Technical Services office for final closure of the examination. (

) This section contains instructions for CCP when a request is received to reprocess a return to the correct TIN or tax period. Note: Do not attempt to reprocess a return when the ASED is expired or (within six months). An account transfer is necessary in this instance. Reference IRM
, Statute of Limitations Processes and Proce- dures. (

) Most requests for reprocessing will come through the FORT. When the comes into the FORT team, CCP will determine if all of the information is available to reprocess a return. If not, instructions are provided to the field group as to what additional information is needed to reprocess the return. Note: If a return has never been processed (i.e. has not posted to another year TIN), attach a Form
, Routing Slip, or local routing slip, and forward

4.4 AIMS Procedures and Processing
On the module to which the TC
return is being moved: a. To increase or decrease the tax, input TC
X using the appropriate reference numbers. If transferring a credit to the module, use an ate hold code to prevent an erroneous balance due notice from being issued. b. If the TC
will be the original return for the receiving module, input adjustment using a refile DLN blocking series
X. If the TC
is an amended return for the receiving module, input the adjustment using an appropriate non-refile DLN blocking series. c. Use Priority Code
on the adjustment to allow the adjustment to post while the -L freeze is on the account. d. Cross out the incorrect TIN/tax period on the TC
return and enter correct TIN/tax period. (It is not necessary to edit anything else on the return.) e. Attach the TC
return to the adjustment document. On the module from which the TC
return is being moved: a. Input TC
for

(zero) (use appropriate hold code) to release the -A freeze. If transferring credits, use an appropriate hold code to prevent erroneous refund from being issued. b. Transfer any credits which do not belong on the module (use TC
if necessary). c. Input TC
AC

4.4 AIMS Procedures and Processing
) If a return being reprocessed contains an FTD penalty computed from that which would be computed under current processing: Returns a. Verify the correct penalty amount. to Deposit b. See IRM

, Failure to Deposit Penalty, for more information. c. Edit a computer Condition Code (CCC) “J” if the taxpayer provided a Other than explanation for non-assertion of the FTD penalty based on reasonable Computation cause. See IRM
, FTD Penalty Relief. (

) First conduct in-house research by verifying the return computation to FTD information was correctly entered. If an error is found due to addition, on subtraction, transposition of numbers or misapplied entries: Return a. Correct the deposit amount claimed on the return and, b. Reprocess the return to the correct module if necessary. (
) If FTD payments are missing or misapplied, research the FTD Credit (MFT
, tax period
), the “Unidentified Remittance File” and prior subsequent tax periods to locate payments. (
) Transfer any erroneously posted payments to the correct modules. See
, Credit Transfers. (

) When resolving reprocessing return conditions involving returns subject to FTD penalty, compare the “Record of Federal Tax Liability” (ROFTL) the return against deposits and payments posted to the modules involved. applies to returns posted to correct modules as well as those being repro- cessed to other modules. (
) If deposit and credit amounts posted to a module differ from the return tax liability by $
or more, perform research to resolve any discrepancies. (
) Before closing the case, check IDRS to see if a CP
notice or a CP notice was issued. If so, coordinate with Accounts Management to prevent erroneous FTD penalty assessments.
